description: This is a file containing data on ritual sites of Britain & Ireland, currently holding dummy data.
name: Ritual Sites of Britain & Ireland

sites.description: An early Roman period temple set around a natural spring with an adjoining bath complex. There is some evidence to suggest that the spring had some ritual significance prior to the Roman structure, it has also been shown that the ritual use of the site continued strongly into the 4th Century with continued deposition of coins, defixiones, and modifications to the temple itself. Aquae Sulis is unique in that it is one of the few sites we have a contempory reference to in Solinus, De Mirabilibus Mundi, Capitula XXIIII.

sites.description: A beehive like Roman structure throught possibly to be a shrine to victory built in the wake of Agrocola's campaigns in Scotland. Nothing now stands of the structure as it was demolished in 1743.

sites.description: Largely known for the Ashwell hoard, the site is a complex not only including a temple, but also a shrine enclosing a springhead, accommodation, and workshops. There are other nearby temple sites at Barkway and Aston.

sites.location: England, Tyne and Wear, Newcastle-upon-Tyne, Broomridge Avenue
sites.description: We know the temple was destroyed sometime in the 2nd Century. The latest coin issue was dated to 161 - 180 and there is evidence of burnt roof tiles and timbers, however, there is evidence of continued use as a burial ground. If the suspected burial just to the west is to be included we can push it's use to the 6th or 7th Century.

sites.description: Two circular temples set about 20ft apart.

The earliest ritual activity recorded at Chelmsford begins in 60 AD and shows continuous activity until the early 5th. The latest coin issue found on the site dates from 388 - 402 AD with the distinct possibility of later activity. The sites demise is likely connected to the end of the Roman town in which it sat to the east. Wickenden suggests a dedication to Mars.

sites.description: A site with two temples, the earlier is described as a circular shrine, the later is a square temple. Located on the edge of a ridge beside the river Ock. For the later square temple (Frilford 2), Lewis (1966) suggests a chronology beginning in the later 1st CE, annexes were added in the late 3rd CE and early 4th CE, and fell into 'decay' at some point in the 5th CE.

sites.description: A site excavated in 1982 that showed a large and popular site centered around an Octagonal temple which started out as a smaller circular shrine. Wedlake suggests that the initial shrine was constructed soon after 69 CE and no later than 210 CE, the site was built up over time and possibly re-used as a church and homestead while a small part of it was used for worship until around 370 CE.

sites.description: A ritual site showing activity from the mid 1st to the late 4th CE. Earliest phases show little evidence for structure, but a later circular temple was built before it collapsed and a Romano-British temple was constructed just to the South. It is notable for the priestly regalia found associated with the site.

sites.location: England, Dorset, South Perrot, Picket Lane, Picket Farm
sites.description: A Neolithic oval barrow which shows evidence for Roman period ritual activuty. Dating is primarily through coin depositons, the bulk dating from 260 to 378 but the earliest is from 117. Some Roman roof tiles were found, the excavator suggested the possibility of a Roman shrine but this was not discovered.

The site is suggested to have activity beginning in the Late Iron Age with a timber-framed wattle and daub temple built in the later 3rd Century. There are several periods of activity and reconstruction lasting into the early 5th Century. Turner suggested that one of these phases was a church.
bibliography: Green, (1999)
Rodwell, (1993)

sites.location: England, Somerset, Bristol, Chewstoke, Pagans Hill
sites.description: A double octagonal temple built in the late 3rd Century CE, the original building, and a second collapsed before the final structure was built in the late 4th century CE. The last building collapsed some time in the 5th century CE. There is pre-roman use noted and post-roman material from the 7th century was found in the adjacent well.

sites.description:
A probable Romano-British temple of uncertain date, the site has been known since the 50s when it was observed as a cropmark (King, Soffe, 1983). The site consists of two concentric masonry foundations (17.5m x 16m) and (8.5, x 7.5m) enclosing a slightly off-centre rectangle which has been interpreted as a possible foundation of a plinth, altar, statue, or else a pool or well. The entrance is more than likely on the east side, though this is not clear from aerial photography.

The site (SU 8090 0644) overlooks a nearby stream at the bottom of a gentle slope to the east. Just outside the temple between itself and the river is a large circular structure with a large central depression 21m in diameter and an encircling ditch of 31m in diameter. Rudling postulates an earlier shrine or location for depositions.

No excavation has been carried out so the date can only be suggested from surface level finds. The earliest finds are Late iron age pottery and coins (Rudling, 2008). The bulk of pottery is late first and second centuries, but one sherd may be third or fourth century (King, Soffe, 1983).
bibliography: Rudling, D., (2008), Roman-Period Temples, Shrines and Religion in Sussex, in Ritual Landscapes of Roman South-East Britain
Mountstephen, S., (2007)
Allison, (2006)
King, A., Soffe, G., (1983), A Romano-Celtic Temple at Ratham Mill, Funtington, West Sussex
(1963), Joint Arch. Comm. Bull, xiii, 1

sites.description: Richborough Castle began as a temporary millitary camp for Plautius' invasion force in 43 AD, the only settlement prior to this was an Iron Agen farmstead that was abandoned around 100 BC. At the end of the first century AD timber structures were cleared away and the site became a more permanent civilian settlement with an associated port. In the late third century AD the site again became a millitary establishment, the central part of the town was leveled and the monument constructed to celebrate the conquest of Britain was converted into a signal station, this signal station was eventually leveled to construct a shore fort. Around this time, it is suggested that the two Roman-Celtic temples to the south were constructed. By the end of the fourth century the fort was no longer garrisoned by regular troops, though the fort continued to be used as a settlement into the fifth century where it is noted in the Notitia Dignitatum. Around this time the temples would have already collapsed but continued to be used as two deposits were found inserted into the wall, it is around this same time that the proposed church associated with the baptismal font was constructed. It is unsure when these structures stopped being used but the fort was abandoned during the later fifth and sixth centures.

sites.description: A possible Late Iron Age and Roman temple, interpreted entirely through aerial photogrophy of crop-markings. There appear to be too overlapping features, a circular enclosure and a square enclosure enclosing a smaller square. It's possible the circular enclosure is a Late Iron Age shrine and the square one a Romano-Celtic temple.

sites.description: A possible temple site, where sample trenching in 1989 uncovered numerous 3rd to 4th century coins and stone relief of a Genius, broken in antiquity. The Genius reportedly stood in an aedicula. A relief of a rider-god was re-used and set into the mill in 1853, judging by the inscription.

sites.description: A scheduled site first observed from aerial photography. The site is triple-ditched and forms a square enclosure with a probable South-East entrance.

sites.description: A square Romano-Celtic type temple four-miles north east of Oxford and built on top of a hill. First refered to in 1841 by Hursey, who mentions traces of buildings at the site. Though the Saxon charter of Eaton (904 CE) may refer to the site as faga flora (coloured floor), referencing mosaics, but this not certain. Excavations in 1952 revealed a two-period temple, the earlier of which was dated to the 1st century CE, less is known about the second phase but it was probably constructed in the mid 2nd century CE. Iron Age occupation at the site has been shown but this is not neccesarily continuous and no structure is known.

sites.description: An early if not the earliest ecclesiastical site in Scotland. The site was purportedly founded by St.Ninian in 397 CE when he constructed a church known as the Candida Casa ('The white hut' in Latin).
An early Irish ecclesiastical site, purportedly founded by St.Éogan in the late 6th CE. According to his Vita Éogan studied at Clones and Whithorn, before founding Ardstraw in his later life.

An early 6th CE monastic site in Ireland, county Monaghan. Purportedly founded by St.Tigernach mac Coirpri who is reported to have died of the plague in the mid 6th CE. The site was dedicated to the Apostles Peter and Paul.
A monastic settlement founded by St.Comgall where he died in the late 6th CE or early 7th CE.
sites.location: Ireland, County Down, Bangor, Belfast Lough, opposite Carrickfergus

sites.description: A monastic site associated with St.Olcán (fl. 5th CE), presumably founded in the later 5th CE. Tírechán records that the lands attached were later seized and regranted to St.Mac Nisse (died 514) and a Senán.
Purportedly founded by St.Patrick around 445, the site became a major monastic site and the head church of Ireland.
Founded by St.Columba around 554 after the land was granted by Ard Rí Diarmait mac Cerbaill. The site is now most famous for it's association with the Book of Kells.
Founded around 520 by St.Finnian. St.Finnian purportedly based his monastery on training he received at Tours and Llancarfan.
A monastic site founded by St.Mobhí in the early 6th CE.

sites.location: Scotland, Inner Hebrides, Argyll and Bute, Isle of Iona
sites.description: A monastery founded by St.Columba in 563 and became an influential centre of Christianity and learning for western Scotland.
The abbey is believed to have been founded by St.Finnian in 540 under the patronage of the Dál Fiatach.
Purportedly founded by St.Ciarán of Clonmacnoise in 544. Ciarán died of a plague 5 years later in 549 and was reportedly buried under the original church, a small wooden structure.

sites.location: Ireland, County Laois, Mountrath, Mayborough West
sites.description: A monastery site in County Laois purportedly founded by St.Fintan. The date 548 CE for its founding has been suggested but this is not certain.
An early monastic site purportedly founded by St.Ciarán the Elder sometime in the mid 5th CE.
A monastic site purportedly founded St.Brendan of Birr sometime in the mid or late 6th CE.
A monastic site purportedly founded by St.Columba of Terryglass, a disciple of St.Finnian of Clonard.
An early monastic site purportedly founded by St.Ruadhán in the mid 6th CE.

sites.description: A pair of square temples in their own temenos, 4 the southern and 5 the northern of the pair. They lie c. 200 yards north-east of the temenos of Colchester 2 on the river-plain. Lewis (1966) suggests a chronology ranging from the mid 1st CE to the late 4th CE. The earlier temple, 4, is suggested to have been built in wood around the year 50, before being destroyed by fire and rebuilt in stone around the year 75, a porch was added in the 3rd CE. The second temple, 5, is comparably short lived, being built in the later 1st CE and falling out of use by the later 2nd CE.
bibliography: Lewis, (1966), Temples in Roman Britain

sites.description: A Roman period mausoleum with a Norman church built on top of it, now abandoned.

Also known as Colchester 1, the Temple of Claudius in Colchester now forms the base of the Norman Colchester castle. Lewis suggests a construction time of mid 1st CE and fell out of use in the late 4th or at the latest early 5th CE (this may be an assumption of Lewis'). It is believed to have been sacked during the Boudican revolt of 60 - 61 CE, and that it was the centre of the Imperial Cult for Britain (though it may have moved to London later).

sites.description: A small Romano-Celtic temple located at 54-56 Gresham Street excavated in 2006. It sits just south of the Roman amphitheatre next to the temple at 30 Gresham Street.

Bateman, N., Cowan, C., Wroe-Brown, R., (2008), London’s Roman Amphitheatre: Guildhall Yard, City of London, London, MOLAS

sites.description: A large aisled building revealed during excavations at Colchester House, near the Tower of London in 1993. It has been suggested that the layout is comparable to the Cathedral of St. Tecla, Milan. It is not certain whether this is a church or some kind of public storage space.
bibliography: Hall, J., Shepherd, J., (2008), Places of worship in Roman London and beyond, in Ritual Landscapes of Roman South-East Britain
Sankey, D., (1998), Cathederals, granaries, and urban vitality in late Roman London, in Roman London: Recent Archaeological Work, pg. 78-82

sites.description:
A large octagonal building surrounded by what appears to be an ambulatory was constructed sometime after 120 CE on the site of the modern Old Bailey building. Prior to this the site appears to have been the center of the glass working industry in Roman London.

The structure has been interpreted as a Romano-Celtic temple, though not much more is known and Perring and Brigham now prefer to interpret it as a 'secular' structure.
sites.location: England, London, Old Bailey, Warwick Passage
bibliography: Hingley, R., (2018), Londinium: A Biography

Shepherd, J., Wardle, A., (2015), The Basinghall Glass in Context, in Glass working on the Margins of Roman London: Excavations at 35 Basinghall Street, City of London, 2005, London, MOLAS, Monograph 70

sites.description: A small classical temple built just to the west of the first forum in the east of Roman London, built at the same time, around 75 CE. The temple lay roughly 10 metres west, on the outside of the forum, now under the building between Lombard St and Bell Inn Yard. The temple was short lived and was demolished while the second, much larger forum was being constructed around 100 CE - 130 CE. No new temple was built to replace it.
bibliography: Hingley, R., (2018), Londinium: A Biography
Hall, J., Shepherd, J., (2008), Places of worship in Roman London and beyond, in Ritual Landscapes of Roman South-East Britain
Lewis, (1966), Temples in Roman Britain

sites.description:
A shrine is suggested to have been somewhere under the modern Goldsmith's Hall. Masonry foundations are reported to have been recorded there, and a probably 2nd CE altar with an image identified as Diana was found there.

It's also notable that the site is only roughly 300 metres north-west of the two Gresham Street temples.
bibliography: Hall, J., Shepherd, J., (2008), Places of worship in Roman London and beyond, in Ritual Landscapes of Roman South-East Britain
Perring, D., Brigham, T., (2000), Londinium and its Hinterland: The Roman Period, The archaeology of Greater London, pg. 135
Toynbee, J., (1962), Art in Roman Britain

sites.description:
A Romano-Celtic temple located in the east of modern day Greenwich Park. The site is located on a hill-top which would of been along Watling Street before it went on to Roman London. The site had an incomplete inscription dedicating the temple to the Imperial Divinities, as well as a roof tile with the London procurial stamp, suggesting that the temple was built on imperial order.

There are associated buildings such as a guest house, as well as a free standing statue of Diana Venatrix.
sites.location: England, London, Greenwich Park, Roman Temple (Ruins)
bibliography: Hayward, K., Coombe, P., Grew, F., Hennig, M., (2015), Roman Sculpture from London and the South-east, Corpus Signorum Imperii Romani, Great Britain, 1, 10, pg. 33- 34

sites.description:
A site interpreted as a Roman-Celtic temple on the location of a Flavian period mansio built around 74 CE, the temple was probably built around the same time.

Of note is a column base with a dedication to Silvanus and an associated bathhouse.
sites.location: England, London, Southwark, 11-15 Borough High St
bibliography: Hingley, R., (2018), Londinium: A Biography
Perring, D., (2015), Recent advances in the understanding of Roman London, in The towns of Roman Britain: the contribution of commercial archaeology since 1990, pg. 20-43

sites.description:
Two temples were constructed alongside the riverside wall (roughly modern Castle Baynards St). One, under the south-east quadrant of the Salvation Army International HQ building, and the other just to the west on Peter's Hill. The two temples were built not long after much of the complex appears to have been demolished for refurbishment and to sure-up the riverside wall. 

It appears that the temples may have never been actually completed. Due to the dating of dendrochronology allowing us to establish the beginning of construction so tightly (spring to summer 294 CE), it has been suggested the construction was initiated by Carausius as a project to promote his authority during the Carusian Revolt and that the project was never finished due to the assassination of his successor Allectus and the re-conquest of Britain in 296 CE.

Bradley and Butler have suggested that the temples may be a kind of 'succesor' to the earlier monumental apses which had been destroyed earlier and are roughly in the same location. They have also suggested that these apses were temples or shrines to Jupiter and Isis, so these later temples may have been intended to be dedicated to the same deities.
sites.location: England, London, Peter's Hill and Salvation Army Headquarters
bibliography: Perring, D., (2015), Recent advances in the understanding of Roman London, in The towns of Roman Britain: the contribution of commercial archaeology since 1990, pg. 20-43
Hall, J., Shepherd, J., (2008), Places of worship in Roman London and beyond, in Ritual Landscapes of Roman South-East Britain
Perring, D., Brigham, T., (2000), Londinium and its Hinterland: The Roman Period, The archaeology of Greater London, pg. 135
Williams, T., (1993), Public buildings in the south-west quarter of Roman London, CBA Research Reports, 88

sites.description: A site excavated in 1967, it was described as a small 'temple-like' building, it formed a single room with an eastern facing entrance and evidence for red and pink painted walls.
sites.location: England, London, St. Dunstan's Hill, Lower Thames Street
bibliography: Schofield, J., Guildhall museum archive guide - draft

sites.description:
Two Romano-Celtic temples built in the later 2nd CE in a temenos that may have been pre-existing for a number of years. The north temple appears to have been dedicated to Mars Camulus early on, there is also another dedication relating to the imperial cult.  

During the 3rd CE the temples appear to have become much more popular, as a substantial structure was built to the south-east and is interpreted as a guest house, while to the north-east, an area with several plinths that could of been bases for statues has been interpreted as a gathering area.

The southern temple had been demolished some time in the later 3rd CE, while the northern one continued in use. It has been suggested that use of the northern temple didn't continue much longer after the late 4th CE as this seems to be when the dedication to Mars Camulus was deposited in a pit, but this isn't certain.
sites.location: England, London, Hankey Place Gardens, 20 Pilgrimage St
bibliography: Hingley, R., (2018), Londinium: A Biography
Shepherd, J., Killock, D., Gerrard, J., Hayward, K., Riellyand, K., Ridgeway, V., (2015), Temples and Suburbs: Excavations at Tabard Square, Southwark, London, Pre-Construct Archaeology, Monograph 18

sites.description:
The Temple of Isis is only known from two inscriptions, the first is a jug from Tooley Street which read ''To London at the temple of Isis", and the second of which is an altar from the riverside wall at modern Cast Baynards St which records the refurbishment of the temple due to disrepair sometime around the 250s CE.

It is not known where the temple was or whether these inscriptions refer to a single site or two. Bradley and Butler suggest that one of the monumental arches that formed the riverside corners of the public complex in the south-west of Roman London may have been a temple or shrine to Isis, as they appear to have the space for a central statue. It is not suggested which it may have been, but the other may have been the Temple of Jupiter, recorded as being refurbished around the same place and time.
bibliography: Hall, J., Shepherd, J., (2008), Places of worship in Roman London and beyond, in Ritual Landscapes of Roman South-East Britain
Williams, T., (1993), Public buildings in the south-west quarter of Roman London, CBA Research Reports, 88
Lewis, (1966), Temples in Roman Britain

sites.description:
The Temple of Jupiter is a Temple that would of been located in the southwest quadrant of Roman London. We only know about it from an altar that recorded it's refurbishment after falling into a state of disrepair some time in the 250s CE. The altar was found re-used as building material in the riverside wall (which runs roughly along modern Castle Baynards St) which was constructed to sure-up the unstable land sometime around 270 CE.

This leads us to believe that it was probably part of the public precinct immediately to the north, Bradley and Butler suggest it may well have been one of the monumental apses that formed that the riverside corners of the complex and each appear to have had the space to hold a statue. It's not known which it might have been, but the other may have been the Temple of Isis, also recorded as being refurbished around the same time and place.
bibliography: Hall, J., Shepherd, J., (2008), Places of worship in Roman London and beyond, in Ritual Landscapes of Roman South-East Britain
Perring, D., Brigham, T., (2000), Londinium and its Hinterland: The Roman Period, The archaeology of Greater London, pg. 135
Williams, T., (1993), Public buildings in the south-west quarter of Roman London, CBA Research Reports, 88
Lewis, (1966), Temples in Roman Britain

sites.description: A single inscription from beneath the Bloomsbury building on the Queen Victoria St side. The inscription references a shrine or temple which had been restored by the district. The site of the shrine is unknown but it was probably in the proximity.
bibliography: RIB 2. Dedication to the Mother Goddesses, available at: https://romaninscriptionsofbritain.org/inscriptions/2

sites.description: A small wooden structure just to the South-East of and pre-dating the original site of the London Mithraeum which has been traditionally identified as a shrine. It appears to have been a wooden platform against a wall with decorative arcaded and ribbed wood paneling on-top of which was a face pot, flint, Iron rust, some kind of tool and a bone ligula. It was destroyed by fire in the early 2nd CE.
bibliography: Hingley, R., (2018), Londinium: A Biography
